thread.title: Greek tourism on the rebound despite debt but Bali holidays down
thread.title_full: Greek tourism on the rebound despite debt but Bali holidays down

author: Robyn Ironside National Travel Writer
title: Greek tourism on the rebound despite debt but Bali holidays down
text:
EXCLUSIVE
THE Greek debt crisis is proving no deterrent to holiday-makers who continue to flock to the European country in growing numbers.
But the opposite is true of Bali, Indonesia, where a persistent volcanic ash cloud has caused chaos for travellers resulting in a noticeable downturn in bookings. Pesky ... Mount Raung blows its top again causing ongoing problems for Bali’s tourism industry. Pic: AFP Source: AFP
A report by Escape Travel , provided exclusively to News Corp Australia, found that trips to Greece surged 18 per cent this month with September and October bookings up eight per cent.
The increase comes despite the country’s financial woes resulting in limited availability of cash from ATMs and banks.
In contrast, the Bali ash cloud has delivered a severe blow to the Indonesian holiday isle with travellers now looking elsewhere.
Australian Federation of Travel Agents CEO Jayson Westbury said the tale of the two destinations spoke volumes about Aussie holiday-makers. Hotspot ... Greece remains a favourite destination for Australian travellers in the wake of the financial crisis. Pic: Yorgos Karahalis/Bloomberg Source: Bloomberg
“Aussies love an adventure, and the news reports on Greece and its financial problems tended to present the country as an adventurous place,” Mr Westbury said.
“Also Australians like to support countries where no physical harm is going to come to anyone. “(The financial crisis) wasn’t a natural disaster, it was a bit of an adventure.”
On the other hand, Bali visitors were caught up in an “unavoidable natural disaster” that had left a lot of people financially out of pocket.
“It’s definitely having an impact (on bookings),” said Mr Westbury.
“People want to have some certainty when they book a holiday so they’re looking at other islands like Fiji and the Philippines.”
Brisbane-based freelance photographer Rob Maccoll said his 10-day Bali holiday had turned into a three-week ordeal that had cost him work and hundreds of dollars in phone calls to Virgin Australia.
“A lot of the locals are complaining about loss of business and cancellations,” he said. No dramas ... Joanne Faraos, of Sydney, had a trouble-free holiday in Greece at the peak of the financial crisis. Pic: Supplied Source: Supplied
Escape Travel general manager Darren Lloyd said he was expecting a downturn in bookings for Greece as a result of the financial crisis, but the opposite seemed to occur.
“The growth in bookings is a great sign and the country remains a firm favourite,” said Mr Lloyd.
“The strong tourist interest is surely a welcome result for Greece where tourism accounts for almost 20 per cent of the country’s Gross Domestic Product.”
Sydneysider Joanne Faraos who spent much of July in Greece said she experienced few problems.
“We didn’t experience anything negative, and unlike the locals, we could access money from the ATMs and still use our bank cards as normal,” said Ms Faraos.
